abstract: U.S. trade groups gave the Chinese government an earful last week about new policies that could hamper the ability of major technology multinationals to do business in China.
snippet: U.S. trade groups gave the Chinese government an earful last week about new policies that could hamper the ability of major technology multinationals to do business in China.
lead_paragraph: United States trade groups gave the Chinese government an earful last week about new policies that could hamper the ability of major technology multinationals to do business in China. Now, in a letter addressed to key United States officials, including Secretary of State John Kerry, 17 trade groups headlined by the United States Chamber of Commerce urged the government to resist the Chinese policies, according to a copy of the letter viewed Thursday by The New York Times. The letter called for the United States government to take “immediate action to work with Chinese officials to reverse an alarming number of troubling, new Chinese government policies impacting the information and communications technology sector.”

headline.main: U.S. Business Group Urges Resistance to Chinese Policy
headline.print_headline: U.S. Business Group Urges Resistance To Chinese Policy

abstract: The Chinese affiliates of the firms failed to produce documents from their audits of Chinese companies under S.E.C. inquiry.
snippet: The Chinese affiliates of the firms failed to produce documents from their audits of Chinese companies under S.E.C. inquiry.
lead_paragraph: The Chinese affiliates of the Big Four accounting firms have agreed to pay a combined $2 million as part of a settlement with the Securities and Exchange Commission over their failure to produce documents from their audits of Chinese companies under investigation by the agency.

headline.main: 4 Accounting Firms’ China Affiliates Agree to S.E.C. Settlement
headline.print_headline: Four Accounting Firms Agree to an S.E.C. Settlement

abstract: Both Kantar Worldpanel and Canalys, research firms that track global smartphone sales, said Apple’s mobile operating system gained market share in China at the expense of Google’s Android.
snippet: Both Kantar Worldpanel and Canalys, research firms that track global smartphone sales, said Apple’s mobile operating system gained market share in China at the expense of Google’s Android.
lead_paragraph: When Apple reported a record-shattering profit of $18 billion last month, the company said its growth came largely from sales in greater China. This week, some research firms gave a clearer picture of just how big Apple has become in China.

headline.main: New Data Shows Apple’s Explosive Growth in China
